TIDM-IDP-01.name: Enterprise Directory Service
TIDM-IDP-01.description: On-premises directory (Active Directory, OpenLDAP, FreeIPA) providing centralised authentication, authorisation, and account lifecycle for domain-joined assets. Kerberos/LDAP as primary protocols.

TIDM-IDP-02.name: Cloud Identity Provider
TIDM-IDP-02.description: Cloud-native IdP (Entra ID, Google Workspace Identity, AWS IAM Identity Center) providing SSO, MFA, conditional access, and directory services as a managed service.

TIDM-IDP-03.name: Federation Broker / Identity Hub
TIDM-IDP-03.description: Third-party identity platform (Okta, Ping Identity, OneLogin) that federates between multiple upstream directories and downstream service providers. Acts as the trust anchor for SaaS and cloud access.

TIDM-IDP-04.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Provider
TIDM-IDP-04.description: Dedicated MFA service (Duo Security, RSA SecurID, YubiKey infrastructure) providing step-up authentication. May be standalone or embedded within a cloud-idp or federation-broker.

TIDM-IDP-05.name: Privileged Access Management Vault
TIDM-IDP-05.description: Credential vault and session broker (CyberArk, BeyondTrust, Delinea) managing privileged account credentials, just-in-time access provisioning, and session recording.

TIDM-IDP-06.name: Customer Identity and Access Management
TIDM-IDP-06.description: External-facing identity platform (Auth0, AWS Cognito, Azure AD B2C) managing customer/partner identities with self-service registration, social login, and consent management.

TIDM-IDP-07.name: Certificate Authority / PKI
TIDM-IDP-07.description: Internal or external CA (ADCS, EJBCA, Venafi, Let's Encrypt) issuing X.509 certificates for TLS, code signing, device identity, and user authentication.

TIDM-IDP-08.name: Device Trust / Endpoint Identity
TIDM-IDP-08.description: Device identity and posture assessment platform (Intune, Jamf, CrowdStrike Falcon Zero Trust) providing device compliance signals as authentication context.

TIDM-IDP-09.name: Workload Identity Provider
TIDM-IDP-09.description: Machine-to-machine identity infrastructure (SPIFFE/SPIRE, Kubernetes service accounts, cloud IAM roles) issuing short-lived credentials for workloads without human interaction.

TIDM-IDP-10.name: Network Access Control
TIDM-IDP-10.description: NAC system (Cisco ISE, Aruba ClearPass, ForeScout) authenticating devices and enforcing network-level access policies based on identity, device posture, and location.

TIDM-POL-01.name: Conditional Access Policy
TIDM-POL-01.description: Context-aware access decision evaluating user identity, device compliance, location, application sensitivity, and risk score. Grants, denies, or requires step-up authentication.

TIDM-POL-02.name: Role-Based Access Control Policy
TIDM-POL-02.description: Access governed by role assignments. Users inherit permissions from roles; roles map to job functions. Static role hierarchy.

TIDM-POL-03.name: Attribute-Based Access Control Policy
TIDM-POL-03.description: Access governed by attributes of subject, resource, action, and environment evaluated at decision time. Dynamic, fine-grained, context-sensitive.

TIDM-POL-04.name: Service Control Policy / Permission Boundary
TIDM-POL-04.description: Cloud provider guardrails (AWS SCPs, Azure Management Group policies, GCP Organisation Policies) limiting maximum permissions regardless of IAM role grants. Defence in depth against privilege escalation.

TIDM-POL-05.name: Credential and Authenticator Policy
TIDM-POL-05.description: Password complexity, rotation, MFA enrollment, authenticator type requirements, phishing-resistant credential mandates. Governs credential lifecycle from issuance to revocation.

TIDM-POL-06.name: Just-In-Time Access Policy
TIDM-POL-06.description: Privileged access provisioned on-demand with time-bound elevation, approval workflow, and automatic revocation. Zero standing privileges as the baseline.

TIDM-POL-07.name: Session Management Policy
TIDM-POL-07.description: Session duration limits, idle timeout, re-authentication requirements, concurrent session restrictions, token lifetime governance.

TIDM-POL-08.name: Federation Trust Policy
TIDM-POL-08.description: Rules governing federation trust establishment, maintenance, and revocation. Signing key rotation, assertion validation, audience restriction, claim mapping rules.

TIDM-POL-09.name: Network-Based Access Policy
TIDM-POL-09.description: Access decisions incorporating network context: source IP/range, VPN status, geographic location, network segmentation compliance. Often combined with conditional access.

TIDM-POL-10.name: Data-Centric Access Policy
TIDM-POL-10.description: Access decisions based on data classification, sensitivity labels, DLP rules, and information rights management. Governs who can access what data regardless of application.

TIDM-POL-11.name: API Access and Rate Limiting Policy
TIDM-POL-11.description: OAuth scope enforcement, API key management, rate limiting, throttling, API gateway authorisation rules. Governs programmatic access to services.

TIDM-POL-12.name: Identity Lifecycle Governance Policy
TIDM-POL-12.description: Joiner-mover-leaver automation rules, access certification schedules, dormant account remediation, orphaned account detection. Governs identity lifecycle from provisioning to deprovisioning.

TIDM-PRI-01.name: Human Interactive User
TIDM-PRI-01.description: Employee, contractor, or partner accessing systems via interactive login. Subject to HR lifecycle, access reviews, security awareness training.

TIDM-PRI-02.name: Human Privileged User
TIDM-PRI-02.description: System administrator, DBA, security operator, or other user with elevated access. Subject to enhanced vetting, session recording, JIT access, and PAM controls.

TIDM-PRI-03.name: Service Account
TIDM-PRI-03.description: Persistent non-human account used by applications and services for inter-system communication. Often has standing credentials (passwords, API keys) requiring rotation.

TIDM-PRI-04.name: Managed / Federated Identity
TIDM-PRI-04.description: Cloud-provider-managed identity (Azure Managed Identity, GCP Service Account with Workload Identity Federation, AWS IAM Role) with automatic credential management. No human-managed secrets.

TIDM-PRI-05.name: Workload Identity
TIDM-PRI-05.description: Ephemeral identity issued to containerised or serverless workloads via SPIFFE/SPIRE or similar. Short-lived X.509 SVIDs or JWT tokens. Lifecycle tied to workload lifecycle.

TIDM-PRI-06.name: Device Identity
TIDM-PRI-06.description: Endpoint, IoT device, or network equipment authenticated via certificate, TPM attestation, or NAC protocol. Device posture contributes to access decisions.

TIDM-PRI-07.name: API Key / Token
TIDM-PRI-07.description: Static or long-lived credential used for programmatic API access. Often lacks identity context (no user attribution), rotation discipline, or revocation mechanism.

TIDM-PRI-08.name: External / Federated Identity
TIDM-PRI-08.description: Partner, customer, or third-party identity authenticated via federation (SAML, OIDC) from an external IdP. Trust depends on the external IdP's security posture, which is outside organisational control.

TIDM-FED-01.name: Hub-and-Spoke Federation
TIDM-FED-01.description: Single authoritative IdP (hub) federates to multiple downstream service providers (spokes). Most common enterprise pattern. Compromise of the hub compromises all spokes.
TIDM-FED-01.riskProfile: Single point of failure at hub; hub compromise = total identity compromise

TIDM-FED-02.name: Mesh Federation
TIDM-FED-02.description: Multiple IdPs establish bilateral trust with each other. No single hub. Common in M&A scenarios where each business unit retains its own directory. Complexity grows quadratically with IdP count.
TIDM-FED-02.riskProfile: Trust complexity; any compromised IdP can assert identities to all mesh partners

TIDM-FED-03.name: Cascading / Multi-Hop Federation
TIDM-FED-03.description: Identity assertion traverses multiple IdPs in sequence. AD authenticates, Okta federates, AWS SSO assumes role, cross-account role chain. Each hop transforms or constrains the assertion.
TIDM-FED-03.riskProfile: Each hop is a potential transformation point; signing key compromise at any hop breaks downstream trust; assertion replay risk increases with chain depth

TIDM-FED-04.name: Business-to-Business Federation
TIDM-FED-04.description: Cross-organisational federation for partner access. External IdP asserts identity; relying party maps external claims to internal authorisation. Trust is contractual and often asymmetric.
TIDM-FED-04.riskProfile: Reliance on external IdP security posture; attribute assertion trust; contractual vs technical trust mismatch

TIDM-FED-05.name: Workload-to-Cloud Federation
TIDM-FED-05.description: On-premises or hybrid workloads authenticate to cloud services via federated identity. OIDC federation from Kubernetes to AWS IAM roles; SPIFFE-to-cloud trust. No human credentials involved.
TIDM-FED-05.riskProfile: Misscoped trust policies (overly broad sub or aud claims); OIDC provider impersonation; token replay across environments
